For adding something like this, there is a lighter weight way.<EOL>
Only committers need to sign an ICLA, and software grants are only needed separately for large blobs of pre-existing code.<EOL>
When we''re in Apache, you can contribute by putting it on the Jena JIRA as a patch file.<EOL>
This implies the necessary legal permission for ASF to use the patch just by the act of doing it (the Jira installation has a note about this when you create the entry, I think - we''re all a bit new to Apache processes).<EOL>
Some committer then handles it - I think (we new to this ...) by making sure the project group is OK with it and then applying the patch.<EOL>
Or the other way round.<EOL>
The point is an email goes to the public development mailing list for everyone, inc committers, to see. <EOL>
For added examples, it''s a bit of a no-op, but it means it''s "the project" dciding, not one person in isolation.<EOL>
It''s no work for the contributor - they just upload patch to JIRA.<EOL>
We''d be swamped by (electronic) paperwork otherwise.<EOL>
The full details are:http://www.apache.org/foundation/getinvolved.html.<EOL>
Thins may be a bit slow as we get sorted out but JIRA never forgets.<EOL>
 If you could send it for now to jena-dev@groups.yahoo.com then submit it when we are up and running properly at Apache.<EOL>

Before the migration to Apache Incubator, we used a google group which wasgreat for discussions spanning a long time, and for archiving knowledge.<EOL>
Gitter is really not good at this.<EOL>
And the dev mailing list is fine butit''s not a great UI, there''s no search, etc.<EOL>
1.
Read the documentation and/or source code.
2.
Search gitter, possibly ask a question there.
3.
Search the dev mailing list, possibly ask a question there.
4.
File a Jira ticket.<EOL>
I think we need something between steps 2 and 3 that''s focused on users.<EOL>

A patch wasn't cherry picked earlier for this > 2.
Copyrights 2016-2017 Apache, before Airbnb / you > 3.
License file formatting > > Otherwise it wonit pass the IPMC.<EOL>

Missing license bodies for FooTable v2, jQuery Clock Plugin,<EOL>
Likewise, your NOTICE has copyright 2011-2017, however Airflow hasn''t been > incubating that long.<EOL>
 If you like, you can give origination notices to the > original creators here to specify the original copyright dates.<EOL>
I would challenge the podling to see if there''s a way to simplify their > LICENSE by instead using npm or some other javascript packaging tool to > build a distribution, rather than shipping the dependencies in the source > release, makes it much easier to use.<EOL>
As the podling matures, would be good to see information about the author > switch from an individual to a community (in setup.cfg, its already in > setup.py so may have been a miss).<EOL>
It would be great to see a binary distribution in the next vote to see how > that may work, its not clear how to build it from this.<EOL>

Chasing, prioritising etc.<EOL>

 Especially, as I think we should trust the community to test >>>> and then vote.<EOL>
Fully understand that business priorities can take precedence.<EOL>
The end goal is clearly to have steady, high-confidence, >>>> mostly >>>>> automated, regular releases and it feels like time is best spent >>>> working in >>>>> that direction.<EOL>

Apply bug fixes >>>>>> 2.
Add performance fixes >>>>>> 3.<EOL>

The Incubator PMC requires your report to be submitted 2 weeks before the board meeting, to allow sufficient time for review and submission (Wed, April 05)<EOL>Again, the very latest you should submit your report is 2 weeks prior to the board meeting<EOL>* Any issues that the Incubator PMC or ASF Board might wish/need to be aware of * How has the community developed since the last report * How has the project developed since the last report.<EOL>It is an initial reminder to give you plenty of time to prepare your quarterly board report.

I do agree with the approach of trying to get funding from Apache and having shared resources (e.g.<EOL>I am willing to offer a place in Lab env I am running or to fund an environment in AWS/GCloud if Apache cannot make these kind of resources available<EOL>I will also hold ultimate power to remove access from anyone<EOL>Downside 1) it might not be entirely Apache like.<EOL>2) there is no guaranteed up time 3) I might need to remove it in the future e.g.<EOL>4) No public cloud integration, its a private stack after all<EOL>Upside is that it is not company property<EOL>To my knowledge what Apache offers is more suited for unit tests (ie.<EOL>The "traditional" Apache infra is Jenkins with a pool of machines that they provide.<EOL>If we decide we don''t like it, I think that''s OK, as long as we move forward knowing that any other testing solution can disappear at any time.<EOL>If running in our Lab there is virtually no restriction what we could do, however I will hand select people who have access to this environment.<EOL>I even might ask for a confirmation that you will behave when using our property (dont worry wont cover it with legal wording).<EOL>We could setup a Gitlab instance that mirrors from Apache a kicks off runners to do testing.<EOL>when I change jobs for example :).
